reviewText:
A reboot of the series rather than a true sequel, Driver SF brings something pretty much brand new to a driving/ racing game. It may not suit the series if you think of this game like its predecessors, but this installment of the Driver franchise has a much more lighter tone to it, therefore this new 'shift' feature fits in pretty well. 'Shift' allows you to jump from one vehicle to another that are cruising around on the streets of San Fran (this replaces 'on- foot'). If you get fed up of a car you're driving in, tap one button to shift out of the vehicle, float around the game world, choose a car that's driving about, then tap one button again to enter the vehicle. Simple. The game brings back the Hollywood film driving handling, allowing you to 'drift' or slide around corners in your favourite film car. Whether it be a classic Dodge Charger, Fiat 500, Nissan Skyline, or a Lamborghini I would say there's a car for everyone in this game, which there should be, since there's about 140 to choose from.

The story is about Detective 'John Tanner' once again, and takes place 6 months AFTER Driver 3. Jericho, also from Driver 3, is about to be sent to prison, yet he escapes in a prison van which he then uses as a weapon against Tanner causing a massive crash that sends Tanner in to a coma. The game, 99% of the time, is in Tanner's coma hence why you have this ability to shift and take over a persons body/ vehicle. The story is odd, but makes sense. In the real world Tanner is in a hospital bed, where a TV in is room is switched on and he can hear everything that is being said on the news about Jericho. So, in Tanner's coma dream he is trying to track down Jericho in a made up San Fran world.

There are main story missions that can range from finding info about Jericho, to chases and to learning about shift. Then there's side missions/ activities/ challenges, which there are a lot of. This could range from races, chases, smashing cars, or doing awesome stunts and jumps. There are also movie challenges which are based on classic car films, like Bullit for example. There is also free- drive which you can do pretty much at any point in the game, missions are found driving around in free drive.

Things I like:
The range of missions/ activites- chases, races, etc
The cars- A nice range of vehciles. Whether it be muscle, sports, super. (Even buses and trucks etc)
In- car cam- Nice details and steering movements, one of the best I've seen in a driving game.
Free roam or free drive- Means you can just mess about in your favourite car, causing cop chases and chaos!
Graphics- The graphics aren't too bad for it's time, they're much better on the cars rather than the San Fran itself.
Multiplayer- Both split screen & online are good, but good luck finding people who play on it.
Film director- It's a bit basic, but it just about does the job to take a look back at a cool crash or chase you just did.

Things I don't like:
AI- Suffers some bad rubber banding, sometimes they'll destroy you, then the next they will be nice as pie.
Customisation on cars- Can't choose what colour you want from the garage, it chooses for you! Also, boost is something the game makes you have and they put it on the steering control, so I advise changing control options.
Story- It's a bit weak, it works in the game, but it's just too short.
HUD- Things flashing up on screen quite often and they don't let you have the option to turn any of it off.

8.5/10

reviewText:
I played a lot of the original Driver and absolutely loved traveling through the San Francisco map. When I saw Driver SF on sale a few years ago, I picked it up on a whim to assuage my homesickness.

Driver SF doesn't do a perfect job of recreating the Bay, you'll quickly pick up on the differences if you've ever spent a decent amount of time there, but it does nail the essential elements and creates a beautiful and exciting city to tool around in.

It's not intended for hardcore racing fans, the controls are fairly simple and arcadey, cars drift pretty frequently but they're also easy to control. It doesn't take a long time to master, but it also doesn't get in the way of the fun.

If you've heard anything about the game you've probably heard about the Shift mechanic. It allows you to temporarily possess almost any other driver on the road, and this mechanic alone would make a poor game worth purchasing. Fortunately, Driver SF was already a solid game before adding this to the mix, so it really rises above the pack. Shifting allows for some creative mission design, and very rarely will you feel bored with repetitive race/follow/chase missions that are so common in racing games. Even when you do have those missions, the shift mechanic allows you to approach them in a completely different manner. Shifting is fluid and fun, while I've heard some complaints about your car's AI while shifting, I never noticed too many problems. In fact, one time I shifted during a race and watched as my car somehow found a shortcut I hadn't noticed, passing the first place car and putting a sizeable lead between me and the rest of the pack. The satisfaction of shifting into a civilian car and plowing head-on into rival racers is also hard to match.

The story and the soundtrack were both impeccably managed. While the story takes place in modern SF, the entire game has the feel of a 1970s buddy cop movie. The soundtrack accentuates this, and I find myself listening to the sountrack on Spotify while playing other games because it was so well done. While most racing games don't put a whole lot of effort into story (I can't remember anything of the original Driver's plot), the Driver SF devs clearly put a lot of work into it, with great dialogue between the two protagonists and amazing cutscenes in the style of the aforementioned cop shows. I won't go into detail about the plot, but it was an absolute blast to experience.

Even if you don't like racing games you can fall in love with Driver SF. There's so much character in it you can't help but like it.

reviewText:
For those who want to get to the point quick, buy this game, and if you can afford it, buy the Deluxe Edition. Driver: San Francisco is an extremely well made and outrageously enjoyable title well worth it's full price or lower. Every car model is licensed, from old family sedans to powerful muscle cars to zippy super cars, and everything in between. Driving a heavy vehichle like a bus or a transport truck feels fun and weighty, like your really pushing the car to its limits as you perform burnouts, jumps, and weave between oncoming traffic.

The story so far has been relatively camp, the usual villian breaks out of jail and you are the only one who can stop him, but takes interesting new directions in how it tells that story. One of my favorite parts is how all cutscenes use a fusion of CGI for charachters talking mixed with actual in engine gameplay (Which means you aren't looking at a cutscene that's been prettied up and doesn't look like what you'll see in game.)

For those worried about the Uplay integration, don't be. I was originally of the camp that hated the service, but so long as your system is able to run the game you shouldn't have too much issue with it. Would I rather it be removed entirely? Yes, but I'll give Ubisoft a pass with this, so long as the service isn't discontinued and the game breaks because of it.

For those who need a score, I'll give the game a 9/10.

reviewText:
Having grown up by San Francisco, the setting of this game is just right for me. The music goes a long way to setting the tone, as do the cutscenes, all of which embody 70's era cop movie. Being in San Francisco gives the game lots of opportunities to to exploit elevation with large hills and jumps, something you're incentivized to explore through the Dare system as well.

Driving is fun, though not without some frustration. I'm a big fan of games that let you hold on the accelerator the whole way and control your course with careful steering and application of drift, but this game is anything but. It'll take a lot more planning than that to succeed, and quite often holding the gas at max will make you fishtail or wildly spin in circles. Not that these are bad things, mind you, but like I said, not how I prefer my racing games. Some cars are better at holding a straight line than others too. There's also the matter of traffic. There's a lot of it, and running into it will slow you down significantly. It does help make the world feel full, and sometimes you'll see active police chases going on around you as well, but other times it just feels in the way. While this game certainly isn't as realistic as a proper simulator (and more on that in a second), it is much less forgiving than your average arcadey racing game, so keep that in mind if realistic racers aren't your style.

The thing that sets this game apart is the ability system, most notably the Shift ability. Shift allows you to jump into (almost) any other car in the world and do with it as you will. Chasing down a criminal trying to get away from cops? Shift into a bus in the opposite lane and have them meet an unfortunate accident. You're also often not alone in the car; passengers will talk to you about their troubles or comment on your driving. I've only had a couple repeats so far and most of the lines are pretty funny. You can also boost or ram cars on a shared cooldown or shift instantly between any other car on your team. The game gives you a lot of options in tackling different missions, but cracks start to show up when it takes away these options. For Dares it doesn't matter so much, but full-fledged Challenges where they do things like take away all your abilities and ask you to take out a car quickly become frustrating.

I'm normally not a fan of open world games and end up feeling lost and aimless, but some games, such as this one, do manage to get a hold of me. The building blocks of story missions and Challenges are the same, though story missions tend to be more involved and obviously will have cutscenes strung through them as well. Dares are simpler than either system and take place in free roam, having you accomplish a single task, often with some restriction such as having to do it in first person, do it without hitting other cars, do it in a certain amount of time, and so on. There are a pretty wide variety of missions to take on, but there are a few that are just really bad and show up time and time again. The one where you need to defend an armored van comes to mind, as does the one where you need to smash objects to add time to the countdown. The former Is just repetitive, the latter runs into problems with how cars handle. Too often you don't have the precise control you want and end up missing what should be an easy hit. Traffic is a big problem here too.

The one open world part of this that still feels too open to me is navigation. The game provides very limited options for navigation, requiring you to pause the game to memorize a full size map, multitask trying to read the expanded map that covers your screen while you drive, or trying to read the tiny minimap while you drive. What I'd really like is a Saint's Row: The Third-style GPS, but instead of picking a single endpoint and having the computer plot the route, draw the route you want to take. The road system is quite complex, so putting human intelligence to the task seems like the best option (and perhaps difficulty programming automatic routes may be a reason they weren't included).

The PC port is decent. It runs well enough, though it doesn't have much in the way of options. I do get hiccups sometimes and outright drops to single-digit FPS in the presence of fire. Some textures, such as the ground, will randomly flicker on and off sometimes. I do have to say though, I've never seen such nice looking tire smoke, and it doesn't even trash my wimpy little card like I'd expect.

In short this game is serious fun, but seriously frustrating in places too.

reviewText:
Driver San FransiscoReleased: Sep 2011
Developer: Ubisoft Reflections
Publisher: Ubisoft

Requires UPlay

+ Surprisingly strong single player story, characters have charm and attitude.
+ A lot of soul and jazz.
+ Well built 'sandbox'.  Lots of garages, cars and upgrades to earn through side events.
+ The 'shift' ability which lets you possess drivers of other cars is cool and makes the game feel unique

- Atrocious AI rubberbanding in Race events.
- Car handling and physics barely passable for the time it was released, today's gamers will expect more.
- Feels dated visually, with fairly low quality textures and complete lack of post processing effects.
- Non existent player base.  While online servers are still alive, don't expect to find people to race online against.

Despite some potential dealbreakers listed above I am still admittedly rather enjoying the occational romp around San Fransisco on this game.  The story is written like an oldschool tv show and is generally enjoyable to play through, and its a great game to chill out with and do whatever events you feel like and increasing your car collection.

The main problem I have with Driver San Fransisco is the rubberband AI.  During events and even campaigns, the other drivers stay glued to you.  If you crash, the other cars will slow down to a crawl right around the next corner.  If you drive like a god, so will they.  I get that it is designed to make players of all skill levels feel challenged, but in practice when it is done as blatantly as here it removes all feeling of challenge entirely.  You can quite literally go take a leak at the start line of a race, then catch up with the others and win.

Outside of that issue, which understandably will turn some away from the game, Driver San Fransisco is a pleasant game to relax with.

reviewText:
In Driver San Francisco, you play a cop who was injured in the line of duty, so the entire game (more or less) takes place in his head while he's in a coma.

His coma is what allows him to do seemingly impossible feats, such as transferring himself to any vehicle he sees and temporarily taking over the driver of that car. It's an interesting gimmick and for the most part it works.

Being able to drive around San Francisco, where all the streets and landmarks are recreated, is really nice. I've only been to SF once in my life (I believe it was sometime in the early-to-mid 90s) so it's not like I know the city well or grew up there. Even so, it's neat to see the TransAmerica Pyramid building in the background or drive down Lombard Street.

Something I really like is that real-world cars are used. I can understand why most developers don't do this, but I prefer seeing a Ford or a Nissan to whatever the developer creates as a thinly-veiled in-game analogue. Surprisingly enough, all of the cars can be seriously damaged (with visual markers as well, such as broken windshields and smashed fenders), which is something you don't often see automakers allowing in games.

There are a ton of mission types, so you don't need to stick with the main story, and plenty of vehicles and upgrades to purchase. All of this will likely keep you busy for some time unless you're attempting a speedrun (which really doesn't make much sense to me, but some people apparently enjoy it).

That said, there are some problems with the game.

I use an Xbox360 wired controller and the controls are pretty damn bad. Steering is loose, but somehow overly sensitive at the same time. You'll find yourself skidding out a lot, often right into oncoming traffic.

Admittedly, different cars have different stats, so some handle better than others, but even so, the steering is woefully inadequate compared to games like Grand Theft Auto 5, Saints Row: The Third/Saints Row 4, or even Watch_Dogs.

My biggest gripe is the limitations placed on the city of San Francisco itself. Although you can slowly unlock new areas of the city by playing through the main storyline, you'll be limited by red barriers for most of the game. For most driving situations, this wouldn't be a big deal for me if it weren't also for the high-speed chases or escapes. It's jarring to run into a red glowing barrier (which, fortunately, doesn't damage your car but resets you in a nearby position).

Also, the Dare" missions often require you to reach a certain speed for a predetermined amount of time and doing so is extremely frustrating when you're close but suddenly run out of street to drive on. At the very least

reviewText:
This game has filled a gaming itch I've been trying to scratch for some time: A racing game that strikes a good balance between fun arcade nonsense and skill requiring realism. (At least for a filthy casual/arcade racing fan like myself)
Car-Shifting is part of what makes this balance work. The easy to understand and master shift system adds a lot to the general flow and experience of the game and also allows for interesting twists on the classic racing game formula, Particularly with chases.
The 70's-buddy-cop-car-chase-movie/show vibe also helps keep the tone the right shade of whacky, while still being able to take itself seriously. Right down to the Last time on Driver San Francisco" episode recaps everytime you load a save or begin a chapter. It's like something out of Burn Notice (If you're into that sort of thing). They even have special races based off of classic movie chases. Then you add in this nightmare-ish coma subplot and it all just makes the tone so great.
Cars handle well enough

reviewText:
Driver San Francisco

Positives
- The story is a good concept and executed well, it is an interesting twist compared to normal driving games, this gives a unique feel to it and makes gameplay much more dynamic.

- Relating to the dynamic gameplay, the quick vehicle teleporter in one word, is fun to play around with. Not only are you able to change vehicles but you can do it in a great way, you exit the vehicle from the air, and in the air you can move around before choosing your next car. This makes things like crashes much more fun. For example, say you're driving down a hill at 60MPH, there's a wall right ahead, you teleport out and pick a car which is going across in the other direction and you can watch your car hit the wall, all before you play it back numerous times with the in-game video editor.

- The map is well made and thereâ€™s plenty to explore, once you're driving about there's no more load times and you're free to just cruise around the map, running from the police or being to be the police.

- There's an extensive range of cars to choose from, these range from vans to sports cars, all licensed and well detailed. This makes gameplay even more fun as you can see many of these cars driving around, making the game even more realistic.

Negatives
- Lack of steering wheel / joystick support. Although this isn't a necessarily bad thing for most, it is annoying that a steering wheel can't be used; however the 'WASD' keys still drive fine.

- Multiplayer doesn't seem to work, my best guess is the servers are probably outdated. This is annoying as it does say that there's multiplayer support on the store page, but in honest the single player suffices.

- You're forced to use Uplay. Yep, even though you've bought this game on Steam you have to go through the pointless phase of creating an account for Uplay and then adding friends before you can play the game, this is just an unnecessary step that has been added.

{Overall: 7/10}
TL;DR Good game and story, with a unique concept, but a poor PC port and Ubisoft's Uplay bring this game down to a 7.

Yes, I mark harshly, this is because you can't have a game which is rated a 10/10, another game is always going to be better and there is always going to be small errors with a game, I am sure no company will ever get a perfect game, that's what makes games fun.

reviewText:
Driver is back, and better than ever! Driver SF takes the series back to its roots. It has you only controlling cars, and none of the on-foot sections like some the other recent Driver games. The handling of the cars is incredible, and the Shift mechanic which you use to quickly change between cars is done really well. The story is really crazy, but it's fun and the dialogue is very well written. Online options are also great.

The game has a wide variety of licensed cars, and they do handle differently from each other. There are way too many things to do in the game, lots of things to collect which unlock various challenges and new cars, as well as a crazy amount of events. The story mode should take around 7 hours to complete.

The only problem with this game: NO AE86!

Buy this game, it's incredible.

reviewText:
Driver SF is a great game that could have been pure gold if not for certain flaws.

The good: the sandbox works well, the story is good (somewhat running on tropes), there are tons of great details (the amazing amount of random conversations fro instance), a lot of real-life cars that can be damaged, a vast city to explore and the shift mechanism is pure joy to use.

The bad: invisible walls everywhere (sure, that could not be helped but it could have been handled with more inspiration), challenges/mission that may have not been playtested or just borderline sadist and uPlay that could have been avoided given the modest content it provides.

The ugly: the game is pure drift porn. It seems the developpers got stuck viewing Fast & Furious too many times and that changed their view of the physical world: most of the cars (the ones you're stuck with at the beginning, unfortunately) will spin, shift and stray at the slightest touch on average speed. It could be great if you were not expected to race or take risks. And this is partly a racing game.

It is however a design choice (seeing how much smoke your tires produce, it's a wonder a rubber protection fund has not been created) and maybe this is your thing. But keep in mind that if you like tight controls in a racing game and a good straight learning curve, this game may offer you more frustration than fun.

In a few words: A slightly less enjoyable Burnout Paradise with a good story and a few twists.

No other game allows you to switch cars in real time ( you can even cause a collision with yourself ) and this feature sets this game apart from the rest of the driving games. This is probably the most freedom you can get in a driving game without moving over to GTA, but that's not a very fair comparision.

82/100

reviewText:
After completing this game, I feel I should write a review, so here we go:

Story
The story takes about 8-10 hours of gameplay to complete. I personally found it amazing. The story fits in amazingly well with the gameplay. This however means you pretty much have to watch the cutscenes to know what's going on, but that's no bad thing with this game. This is one of the few games that I've willingly watched the cutscenes, as they are interesting and of good quality.

Gameplay
The gameplay is nice. Alongside the story are many events that you can do anytime, usually including something along the lines of a race, police pursuit or stunt. The story events include similar things, but also have events where you need to protect a vehicle or something along those lines.

Freedrive is very diverse. There are many things to do, such as start a pursuit (as cop or getaway), try to make insane jumps or drive around trying to view the beautiful scenery.

Pursuits are fun. Being a Need For Speed fan, pursuit games are my favourite genre. Although a little easy to not get busted, the cop AI is quite clever and it is sometimes quite hard to get away, especially when driving a bus or flatbed-trailer truck :P

The main focus of the gameplay is shift". John Tanner (whom you play as) is in a coma
date: and the game is pretty much set in his mind. This allows him to "shift"
hoursPlayed: into any body he may choose. This allows you to drive trucks
voteText: buses
votesHelpful: cars
votesTotal:
police vehicles and car transporters.

At the end though he starts trippin' balls and starts throwing cars around and stuff :P Iit gets a bit mental at that point :P

Graphics
The graphics are quite nice
votesFunny: especially on the highest settings. Surprisingly
commentsCount: even poor graphics cards can run it with decent settings at 60 fps

which I think is great considering the standard of the graphics.

Wheel Support
I have a G27 and I can honestly say it works great with this game. If you are considering buying a G27
column18:
it's perfect. Only problem is I have to remap the controls everytime I start the game...

TL: DR
This is a fantastic game for such a price. I've so far gotten 14 hours out of this game

column20: gameplay and storyline. A good buy :)"

reviewText: Driver San Francisco definitely has its goods and bads. When you first purchase the game and try to launch it, it will automatically download uPlay. (It's kinda like steam for UbiSoft games) Unfortunately, when Steam tries to download uPlay, it doesn't work, and the game can't even start up. With a little bit of research, I figured out that you must create a uPlay account and download the application yourself for the game to work. Once I had solved this problem, the game began to run normally... for atleast a little while. During the first cutscene, the game froze, so I had to restart the entire game over... twice. The third time I was able to skip the cutscene, only to find myself having the force stop the game again because it was stuck on the loading screen! On my fourth try, I was finally able to play the game. Once I was able to play, I thoroughly enjoyed the graphics and gameplay, and the freedom of the game. I did, however, have some problems trying to switch the controls. You start out using the arrow keys to accelerate, decelerate, etc, and I looked through the settings. It gives you the option to change the keys, but when you try to choose your desired key, it won't register! (I did plug in my driving wheel {that I purchased from a yard sale a couple months back, lol}, and it worked perfectly!) It was pretty fun for about 30 minutes until the game froze... again!\n\nThis game so far has some major issues, and unless  you have a steering wheel and a huge amount of patience, I would not reccomend this game for you.

It has the usual Driver pros like licensed cars, car chases that hark back to those classic car movies I've never seen and it transitions between two distinct decades!... wait, that was the only really good Driver. I liked some of the missions and the way they present the game generally enough. The shift thing is a cool gimmick and such. The brilliant cutscenes from previous games kind of make a return. Except they don't really look any better and they're layered in with in game footage. Jumping between the two is really quite jarring. Also the voices don't seem to mesh well with the animation.

When driving around all Quantum Leap style Tanner will talk to people in the cars and respond to what they say. Normally it's quite standard for passengers to just shout how terrible you are and the comments go ignored by the player. It's quite a nice touch and can be genuinely funny at times. Oh and there are collectibles, normally I hate them as they detract from the game but these ones are quite easy to find and unlock some pretty awesome challenges based on classic movies. Also if you do get it try driving up to 88mph in a DeLorean and see what happens.

By far the most enjoyable game mode is where you shift into other cars to take out your rivals in a race. It's so satisfying to get overtaken, jump into a semi and U-turn that â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ right into your opponent and then smugly drive by windmilling your â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out the window to show that tosspot AI who's the mo'â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing king of the road. Not that it always works out that way. A lot of the time you'll jump back into your car only to find your traffic jam has screwed your pooch too or worse yet, the AI that takes over from you has just mistaken the days events for a Sunday drive and has let the other racers, two funerals, a biker gang and a band of girl scouts on tricycles overtake you because he's just too â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing polite.

I'ma go ahead and reel off the cons now. In fact lemme tell you about the mission that killed this game for me. An off-road race that I could've smashed through in the Dodge Viper but they saw fit to give me the supposed best off-road car in the game. The one that handles like â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, has as much grip as a wet â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and accelerates like my mum going up a steep incline. After the first 6 times I failed I tried to quit but the unresponsive menus thwarted my efforts.

Unresponsive menus are the absolute worst thing to have in a game that might frustrate you. When you're already â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ to high hell the last thing you want is to fail exiting the game three times because the game can't keep up with your rage. That's how controllers get broken and how I ended up forking out for a new tv.

On top of that there is no way of looking at what songs are in the game nor does it have a menu to select which songs can play like any good open world game with a licensed soundtrack should have. The exception being GTA, that does radio stations more than efficiently and allows for your own muzak. It got to the point where I didn't know what seems to be the only song I was already familiar with before hand was even in the game until literally just after I finished it.

So basically it's okay if you're good at driving games and a fan of the series. I don't think this'll be the game to turn any newcomers onto the franchise. Especially when the other games have aged like they have.

reviewText:
This game has a great story line and great mechanics within tha game allowing for it's re play value to be quite high, However there is so much wrong with the game that I can't recommend people buy it.

The first thing I noticed was an issue with V-Sync, now many people will play with single graphics card solutions so this shouldn't concern them, however those with multiple graphics cards may find that with V-Sync on the framerate drops significantly to 24fps. While it isn't too bad it is an issue to play the game at a lower framerate as it just isn't as fluid.

The next thing; while driving around I noticed that almost every car I used was fairly annoying to control. Adjusting the steering sensitivity did help a tiny bit but the issue is that coming out of corners, the cars would fishtail so heavily that it took a few moments to gain control and by that time you either lose your place or fall behind.

For fans of the series, I would say go for it, it is a lot of fun and a fairly original and well developed story line.

reviewText:
At first I didn't like this game. Every car seems to spin out of control with some doing more than others and the controls were very obviously designed for a controller. But I got used to it and it's quite enjoyable. It's the first racing game I've actually liked probably because of the story. It's weird but fun.

My one complaint is that it's hard to get around. Most of the time you'll want to do that thing where you can see large areas at once but you can't move very fast or see very far. You'd think there would be an option to press another button and zoom out to the whole map. Maybe there is I just didn't find it yet. And there's a world map burried in he menus. I just unlocked a new region but it seems meaningless as I have no idea how much of the map I've actually explored.

There are two types of missions. The blue optional missions and the yellow missions. Don't do the blue ones, they're too hard.

All in all it's a fun game but it doesn't have that 'I need to find out what happens' feeling many other games have.

reviewText:
This game has a great story line and great mechanics within tha game allowing for it's re play value to be quite high, However there is so much wrong with the game that I can't recommend people buy it.

The first thing I noticed was an issue with V-Sync, now many people will play with single graphics card solutions so this shouldn't concern them, however those with multiple graphics cards may find that with V-Sync on the framerate drops significantly to 24fps. While it isn't too bad it is an issue to play the game at a lower framerate as it just isn't as fluid.

The next thing; while driving around I noticed that almost every car I used was fairly annoying to control. Adjusting the steering sensitivity did help a tiny bit but the issue is that coming out of corners, the cars would fishtail so heavily that it took a few moments to gain control and by that time you either lose your place or fall behind.

For fans of the series, I would say go for it, it is a lot of fun and a fairly original and well developed story line.

reviewText:
Honestly, I didn't meet my expectations. I had really high hopes for this game, because the idea in general sounded quite fun and refreshing. But now that I've played it I can't shake the feeling this could've been better.
First of all, the story is ok, let's get that out of the way. It's a bit far fetched maybe, but ok nonetheless.
The graphics get the job done as well, but this is one of the things that disappointed me. The models for the cars are solid, but there's just so little detail in them. I like my cars very detailed, like in GT5 or Forza. Of course I can't expect the same quality for an arcade racer, but it would've been nice to give the most important cars some extra detail. Same goes for the city.
The VOs are pretty good, and the music is alright if you're into that kind of stuff. It wasn't really my taste.
And the gameplay itself is solid; the shifting technique is actually pretty cool and adds a bit of strategy to the game.
Still, it's not full-price-worthy.

[Rating: 82/100]

reviewText:
Although the storyline is solid, and the car models are beautiful, inside and out, the game's physics are atrocious. With only WASD controls, just about every car handles as though it is on ice. Using a race wheel may help, but for those who don't own one, your 2 options of tire-spinning full throttle or locked-up brakes make gameplay quite difficult at the best of times.

Along with the horrid keyboard driving controls, the NPC drivers tend make gameplay even less enjoyable. If civilian cars aren't gluing their rear bumpers to your front when you rear end someone at high speed, swerving with you until you stop, back up, and then swerve around them, the unreliable, inconsistent police AI will drive you mad. In some cases they can be easily outrun on a long, flat stretch, other times they keep up with you at speeds approaching 170 mph (I've clocked them) in vehicles seemingly as strong as tanks that handle like they are glued to the tarmac, while in standard, NPC-started car chases they barely crack 80 and drive like they're going on a Sunday cruise. Adding to the police chases is the cops' tendancy to spawn just ahead of you 2 seconds before you escape, making for incredibly aggrivating runs through San Francisco.

Last but not least is Ubisoft's game launcher. During the quite frequent spells when the launcher will not sync up with the Ubisoft network, the multiplayer game mode is deactivated. Out of my close to 100 hours* in the game, about 70 of those hours were done in 'offline-mode', a shame, as the few times I was able to play multiplayer with friends, even with the terrible controls, much fun was still had.

All in all, the graphics are incredible, the story line well thought out, and the variety of vehicles available is quite impressive, but the poor driving physics and terrible AI really drag the game down, along with Ubisoft's unreliable game launcher. I honestly wonder how the game was rated so high by professional critics.

*Contrary to what my Steam game hours may show, I have actually devoted closer to 100 hours to the game, beating the Campaign mode, and nearly completing all extra challenges. The Ubisoft game launcher system doesn't function too well with Steam when it comes to Steam acknowledging Driver: San Francisco has actually started, and in order to get Steam to recognize I am playing the game, I need to tab back over to Steam once the game has started and press the play button once again, which then 'officially' shows me as playing the game. After a while I got sick of bothering, and just played in 'non-Steam' mode, hence the low Steam hours.

reviewText:
You know what's fun in driving games? Putting you, the player, in a gigantic, slow, heavy machine that handles like a skip full of potatoes with a lawnmower engine. And you have to escape suicidal police cars by weaving through traffic. And it's apparently manufactured using damp toilet paper.

You know what's also fun? Mandatory race missions, where you're given a supercar that feels more like an ice cream van. And your opponents are also suicidal, and have those magical rubber-band engines installed.

The overarching story's enjoyable, in a borrowed Life on Mars? kind of way, and bonus points for having a protagonist character pulled straight from a buddy-cop film; no standard angry, eye-rolling cynicism here. The way the game presents recaps of the plot at every chapter's nice, too - the 'events so far' cutscenes and the traditional blackboard replete with names, photographs and arrows again borrow heavily from TV police procedural shows.

I just didn't like how little things seemed to spoil the experience: there's no GPS guidance besides 'get to X point on the map within Y time', and expanding the mini-map covers up the road in front of you. So you can either risk running into traffic, or jump into the Pause menu to look at the city map at every checkpoint. Not sure if it's a deliberate stylistic choice or not, but an option would have been nice. One other thing - played with a controller, your 'boost' is activated when you push the stick forwards, so it's really, really easy to accidentally trigger when weaving through traffic.

There's also lots and lots of side-content in the form of stunt missions, and 'dare missions' - but they're all along the lines of 'drive for X seconds at Y MPH in oncoming traffic', or 'perform a drift for Z metres'; so there's always something to do, but  not an awful lot of variety. Same goes for the soundtrack: I couldn't name (or even hum) one of the songs that plays in free-roam or in a mission.

...the game also uses uPlay, which is an abomination. Not the game's fault, really, but there you go. Boo, Ubisoft.

If you enjoy goofy buddy-cop films and enjoy arcadey Burnout-like gameplay, but can also look past minor, awkward gameplay complaints, go ahead. The little things annoyed me enough to not recommend, though - and if you're looking for a GTA-like experience, don't bother.

reviewText: I suppose I haven't really given this game a fair chance, but then again I see no reason to either. First of all, only Xbox 360 controller will work (and keyboard controls are simply horrible in this game). Second, if you have an AMD graphics card you will get a lock of 24Hz in full screen so you have to use Fake Fullscreen software to combat this. Third, the in-game graphics are the most pathetic I've seen even on max. Fourth, the driving mechanics are amongst the most ancient and lifeless I've ever come across. Fifth, various problems with starting the game. Sixth, it doesn't do what a driving game should. Eight, too many cutscenes for a racing game. Need I go on? The only thing I can possibly give credit to is the facial detail in cutscenes and that it's actually trying to do a 'Starsky and Hutch' style story, something you don't see in newer racing games. But seriously, if you want a decent game like this either play Starsky and Hutch or Midtown Madness 2 SE. At least with Midtown Madness 2, you know the game has been made by professionals (Rockstar San Diego, published by Microsoft). Driver San Fransisco not only has horrible controls, laughable graphics and driving physics, but also poorly optimised for PC. Unless you have zero experience with racing games you can't possibly think these driving mechanics are acceptable. Sure, you get interior view but what's the use if you can't have manual transmission and the animations and graphics are shockingly bad?

reviewText:
This Driver is welcomed as I didn't like Driver 2 or 3 ( Or the PSP one, Driver 79? Something like that )

This Driver game is about driving and doesn't feel like it's trying to be a third-person shooter which really didn't work!

The cars are obviously American as I saw a lot of Chevrolet's which are pretty rare in the UK anyway...

+ Graphics are pretty nice, a little ugly occasionally.. but near-enough perfect for me...
+ Cars handled nicely, I enjoyed it.
+ Being able to drive anything without punishment is amazing

-Cutscenes looked much better than the game (This bothers me a lot)
-Physics sometimes glitched but.. this is a minor complaint...
-Storyline was short and personally a bit boring and random...

Overall probably 7/10 sounds good to me.. Good driving game, however could've been better!

( NOTE: Get the Normal Driver:SF, the More expensive one adds nearly nothing.. Taxi Mode is just racing in taxis and on Mass Chase you can't be the cops so... )

reviewText:
A seriously atmoshperic game I can't stop playing. It brings back the feeling of the first Driver I played on PS1 a long time ago. The game is full of contents :

1. A hughe San Fransisco is waiting to be explored step by step as progressing in the storyline opens up different parts of the city. Lots of landmarks around, living and breating traffic (even pedestrians who are very good at dodging cars :)) and much more to see.

2. There are endless fun in the missions. The main storyline in chapters, and impressive amount of side missions we can take. I've never seen this extra wide variety of fun related to driving in any games yet. Actually it took a time for me to figure out what and how - at first look it's simply overwhelming. And this game is not easy at all. You may find yourself repeating challenges  until dawn because you fail one try after the other. (Fortunately your career progresses wile you are driving anyway so it's not a waste of time loosing" but serious fun.)

3. The main storyline is absolutely out of the mainstream examples
date: so as the way we can interact with all the cars in the city.\n\n4. Countless cars we can drive. All of them are nicely modelled inside out. Hard to stick to a favourite when a Grand Torino is in my garage but that Charger comes up too. Lots of modern European cars
hoursPlayed:
it's possible to jump even in a bus or truck if you feel. The cars can be damaged until they are useless wreck. Hard to avoid sometimes...

5. It's just brilliant.

6. The graphics are excellent
voteText: sounds and music wonderful and atmospheric - it all feels like being in the '70-80s. A must have for retro lovers.\n\n7. This is an arcade game for sure but I am always cautious using these terms. It's also a simulator if you take a look at how to drift using the handbrake and how loong you need that handbrake pulled
helpfulPercent: when to press the pedal again to accelerate out of a corner
votesHelpful: etc.\n\n8. The multiplayer is also really nice
votesTotal:
many great ideas implemented in driving context. All challenging and fast paced. Actually I would love to see "simple" and "conventional" ways of multiplaying sometimes :)

One (manageable) downside is a strange surprise: the game supports only a few steering wheels. Mine is a Logitech Formula Force FX and I had to make a small detour to make it accepted by the game. (There's a good vid on YT how to make the game accept some controllers.)
So overall I'm a happy guy because I have found this title here on Steam. Highly recommended."

reviewText:
When I saw this game release halfway through 2011, I never would have thought it would become one of my favorite games ever. I've never been much of a fan of driving games. I've tried a lot of them: Burnout, Need for Speed, Forza, Gran Turismo, even the previous Driver games left me lukewarm on the genre. I mean there's only so much one could do with using a car to get to another end of a race. At least, so was thought until this came around.

Using the novel car-swapping mechanic, you can jump in and out of different cars in open world San Francisco as you take on the devious Jericho. The car-swap allows for some great times; you could eliminate your fellow racers with headlong collisons or crash in a spectacular chase and in a couple button presses, be on your way as normal. That's the best thing about this game; the flow. It flows perfectly from car chases to street races to mission stages (:P).

I have a couple minor gripes: the cars seem to spin out pretty easily and the missions sometimes feel a bit unforgiving when I just barely fail them. But even then, they never at any point stopped me from enjoying the game. I recommend this one wholeheartedly and hope that you pick it up!

P.S. There is multiplayer - so if you do get it, let me know. I don't have anyone to play it with.

reviewText:
Really solid / fun cops / robbers / racing game. Loads of variety of missions from scaring driving instructors to evading the police. One interesting addition to the game as many have said already is the ability to take over control of any vehicle on the road (be it school bus or a Ford GT) via the 'coma system' as I call it. Shouldn't work so well on paper when you read it but believe it does. It also adds opportunities to sabotage opposition with other cars on the road (say during a police chase, you could put a big â™¥â™¥â™¥ lorry to block the road behind your chased car) as well as a smart opportunity for random driver character narrative (police banter or say a freaked out passenger spouse) which gives the world a life / realism of it's own.

You also have upgrades, loads of vehicles to purchase and many missions scattered across the high sloped roads of San Fran.

The only negative I could say so far is it doesn't 100% match the moments / focus of the adrenaline / depth of the chase as was the case in the original Driver game where that and it's Director mode were the centre piece, but it's pretty close mostly!

Good times!

DSF uses a pretty cool gimmick that surprisingly doesn't get old: Being able to astrally project yourself outside of your car and into the driver of another. (For unexplained story reasons you can't project into the bad guys you need to catch and just make them stop the car.)

reviewText:
A huge grin appears on my face, a black muscle car sits in front of me, a 60 second countdown starts and I burnout away in the multi-storey car park.
Welcome to Driver: San Francisco. This is the latest full AAA title in the Driver franchise, number five I believe, the encounter in question is an unlockable challenge which pays homage to the opening level of the original game from 1999 on the first Playstation.
Driver for me holds a spot close to my heart as it was the first AAA title I ever owned on my first console the resized PSone. Anyway onto this new version.
You once again step into the shoes of John Tanner, ex racing driver come hard driving cop. San Francisco has taken a step back to the roots of the game series and has gone back to focusing on the driving. You will not be running around or shooting in this game, which is a relief as Driver is all about tearing through back alleys sending tables flying chased by the police in the style of classic car chases in movies.

And this is a good move for the series. Despite the not running about you still have the option to switch the car you are in through the mechanic of â€œshiftâ€ into one of about 90 licenced vehicles all of which have a damage meter which will force you to jump out and try new approaches.

The driving mechanics in this game is pretty solid, the game is an obvious console port, through the lack of graphics tweaking options and the depth of field is shallower than one might expect. I did not see many car pop ins but definitely saw some buildings pop in. The driving as per the rest of the series is very arcade inspired. Drifting, power slides and high speed corners are not a problem in this game, whether in a bus or a zonda.

I tried playing this game with a  keyboard and with a 360 pad and neither seems to be a definitive winner for a driving platform in this game, so down feel put off if you donâ€™t own a game pad.

The story isnâ€™t bad, but itâ€™s not going to win any awards for narrative. The voice acting is good, with a lot of comedy from the leading roles as well as the interactions between Tanner and the passengers of cars that you shift into.
So if you are after an arcade driving game with an open world environment or youâ€™re after a nostalgia trip to a game with its roots back in the nineties then you could do worse than Driver: San Francisco.

Really solid / fun cops / robbers / racing game. Loads of variety of missions from scaring driving instructors to evading the police. One interesting addition to the game as many have said already is the ability to take over control of any vehicle on the road (be it school bus or a Ford GT) via the 'coma system' as I call it. It also adds opportunities to sabotage opposition with other cars on the road (say during a police chase, you could put a big â™¥â™¥â™¥ lorry to block the road behind your chased car) as well as a smart opportunity for random driver character narrative (police banter or say a freaked out passenger spouse) which gives the world a life / realism of it's own.

You also have upgrades, loads of vehicles to purchase and many missions scattered across the high sloped roads of San Fran.

The only negative I could say so far is it doesn't 100% match the moments / focus of the adrenaline / depth of the chase as was the case in the original Driver game where that and it's Director mode were the centre piece, but it's pretty close mostly!

Good times!

reviewText:
Don't let the negative reviews from players or critics turn you off from this gem. Drive: San Fran is a great driving game and keeps me entertained like Burnout Paradise or Midnight Club 3 does and I'm glad I can experience what this game has to offer - both in the singleplayer and multiplayer.

If you have played the demo and did not like the driving, you probably aren't good at driving games or don't like the style of driving. After reading numerous reviews and hearing the bashing of the driving mechanics, I found it fun and satisfying on all counts - especially the faster and more drifter style cars, this goes for online and singleplayer.

The voice acting can be cheesy but the dialog and context of many situations throughout the game put a smile on my face. Think of 'House of the Dead: Overkill' but with less swearing; just over-the-top and fun.

This is a popcorn flick that you control and that is awesome.

reviewText:
DSF uses a pretty cool gimmick that surprisingly doesn't get old: Being able to astrally project yourself outside of your car and into the driver of another. (For unexplained story reasons you can't project into the bad guys you need to catch and just make them stop the car.)

That means you can play Driver as more a straightforward racing game where good driving carries you most of the way, or as a smash-em-up car brawler where much of the work is done by projecting into oncoming traffic and using random civilians to bring down your enemies with head-on collisions.

The presentation is gorgeous, the soundtrack is top-notch, and the writing is funny enough, so long as you don't mind a mostly incoherent story with a lot of contradictions.

It's worth the money.

reviewText:
A huge grin appears on my face, a black muscle car sits in front of me, a 60 second countdown starts and I burnout away in the multi-storey car park.
Welcome to Driver: San Francisco. This is the latest full AAA title in the Driver franchise, number five I believe, the encounter in question is an unlockable challenge which pays homage to the opening level of the original game from 1999 on the first Playstation.
Driver for me holds a spot close to my heart as it was the first AAA title I ever owned on my first console the resized PSone. Anyway onto this new version.
You once again step into the shoes of John Tanner, ex racing driver come hard driving cop. San Francisco has taken a step back to the roots of the game series and has gone back to focusing on the driving. You will not be running around or shooting in this game, which is a relief as Driver is all about tearing through back alleys sending tables flying chased by the police in the style of classic car chases in movies.

And this is a good move for the series. Despite the not running about you still have the option to switch the car you are in through the mechanic of â€œshiftâ€ into one of about 90 licenced vehicles all of which have a damage meter which will force you to jump out and try new approaches.

The driving mechanics in this game is pretty solid, the game is an obvious console port, through the lack of graphics tweaking options and the depth of field is shallower than one might expect. I did not see many car pop ins but definitely saw some buildings pop in. The driving as per the rest of the series is very arcade inspired. Drifting, power slides and high speed corners are not a problem in this game, whether in a bus or a zonda.

I tried playing this game with a  keyboard and with a 360 pad and neither seems to be a definitive winner for a driving platform in this game, so down feel put off if you donâ€™t own a game pad.

The story isnâ€™t bad, but itâ€™s not going to win any awards for narrative. The voice acting is good, with a lot of comedy from the leading roles as well as the interactions between Tanner and the passengers of cars that you shift into.
So if you are after an arcade driving game with an open world environment or youâ€™re after a nostalgia trip to a game with its roots back in the nineties then you could do worse than Driver: San Francisco.

reviewText:
When I saw this game release halfway through 2011, I never would have thought it would become one of my favorite games ever. I've never been much of a fan of driving games. I've tried a lot of them: Burnout, Need for Speed, Forza, Gran Turismo, even the previous Driver games left me lukewarm on the genre. I mean there's only so much one could do with using a car to get to another end of a race. At least, so was thought until this came around.

Using the novel car-swapping mechanic, you can jump in and out of different cars in open world San Francisco as you take on the devious Jericho. The car-swap allows for some great times; you could eliminate your fellow racers with headlong collisons or crash in a spectacular chase and in a couple button presses, be on your way as normal. That's the best thing about this game; the flow. It flows perfectly from car chases to street races to mission stages (:P).

I have a couple minor gripes: the cars seem to spin out pretty easily and the missions sometimes feel a bit unforgiving when I just barely fail them. But even then, they never at any point stopped me from enjoying the game. I recommend this one wholeheartedly and hope that you pick it up!

P.S. There is multiplayer - so if you do get it, let me know. I don't have anyone to play it with.

reviewText:
One of the most fun games of the year, and probably  the best open-world car game ever. It has the wackiness and solid storytelling of GTA, but with a heart (and without the tedious running around on foot). It has the intense cop chases of NFS:Hot Pursuit, but with much more soul. It has nice big open city like Burnout Paradise, but one that has people in it and feels lived in (plus far less annoying crashing).

Overall, a great fun story, some genuinely laugh-out-loud moments, great soundtrack, and great physics that make all the cars believeable but fun and easy to drive.

The shift mechanic rocks. It eliminates the tedium of having to drive back to a garage if you want a different car, it adds a whole other level to the gameplay, and it ties into the story beautifully.

Though like all car games, D:SF is probably only half as fun when you're using the keyboard. A wheel probably is overkill in this one - play it with an xbox gamepad.

reviewText:
One of the most fun games of the year, and probably  the best open-world car game ever. It has the wackiness and solid storytelling of GTA, but with a heart (and without the tedious running around on foot). It has the intense cop chases of NFS:Hot Pursuit, but with much more soul. It has nice big open city like Burnout Paradise, but one that has people in it and feels lived in (plus far less annoying crashing).

Overall, a great fun story, some genuinely laugh-out-loud moments, great soundtrack, and great physics that make all the cars believeable but fun and easy to drive.

The shift mechanic rocks. It eliminates the tedium of having to drive back to a garage if you want a different car, it adds a whole other level to the gameplay, and it ties into the story beautifully.

Though like all car games, D:SF is probably only half as fun when you're using the keyboard. A wheel probably is overkill in this one - play it with an xbox gamepad.

reviewText:
Worth picking-up in a sale.  Decent graphics.  Interesting game mechanic.  Looks like there is lots to see and do in a GTA-style, but confined to (lots of) driving, rather than activities on-foot.

The actual driving seems like it would be fun: throwing big, floaty, American cars around the streets... if only it supported my Thrustmaster T500 wheel!  I can't face going back to other control methods like KB or gamepads, but they probably work OK.  About 10 other (older) Thrustmater & Logitech wheels are, however, supported by the game and you can edit their settings files in folders in the following location if your wheel isn't (Google for further details):

C:\Steam\SteamApps\common\Driver San Francisco\Input.

... At the moment, I can get the game to recocognise my wheel & pedals, but centering and force-feedback won't work.  It really needs wheel centering, at least.  Also, it would be nice if reverse was a gear-option, not something that kicks-in if you hold down the footbrake!

reviewText: Excellent open-world arcade racer with fresh things going for it: the car shifting mechanic lets you troll NPCs on the road by instantly possessing and transferring into their vehicles, leading to some hilarious gameplay situations. Suffering too much car damage? Want to use the oncoming 18 wheeler as an insta-roadblock? How about listening in on some soccer mom's attendant divorce drama? You can do it all. Then there's the excellent soundtrack and sense of style: funk and soul tracks from the 70s, paired with a buddy-cop television serial flavour.\n\nThis would be a great game if it weren't for Ubisoft's slightly off-putting UPlay DRM. Buyer beware.

reviewText:
Nvm the Ubisoft DRM. Nvm the cpu heavy AI (e8400 is stretching it
at times): This Game Is Absolutely Fabulous.

100% bigbudget-movie like car chases: drifting, speeding, sliding, wheelspin, jumping, smashing etc. Very polished production, realistic cars (including plain) with damage, realistic heavy traffic. Single player storyline refreshingly original, plays like a tv-show pilot  (cutscenes & voiceacting +1).
Additional ton of single player stunts, missions and races all over the huge (huge!) fully populated city, to earn more cars and upgrades to special abilities like shifting from car to car.
Multiplayer is a blast (albeit difficult to find public games). Eg. very intense to smash through traffic, tailgating a car to rack up points while opponents try to do the same (other gametypes, ao ctf, race, tag).

This is the definitive Driver game.

Worth noticing before buying this game makes use of UPlay. UPlay is the ubisoft's game library like Steam but than more like his evil twinbrother. I experienced several problems with UPlay in the past, because it actually needs admin rights to start up. (imho riddiculous )

I would recommend picking up the game when it is on sale.

reviewText:
So, let me start this review off by saying that the best game of all time that I have every played is Burnout: Paradise. It was the perfect mix of destruction and exploration, where you could just go around and jump, smash, and crash your way to victory.

Now, Driver: San Francisco is similar to Burnout Paradise, but conveys the claustrophobic environment that wreckless driving despises. The close-quarters, hilly environment of the bay area adds so much more to intense car chases, wailing sirens and all. The physics engine and environment rewards the player greatly for tight vehicle handling and situational awareness. The dreamy lighting makes the game teeter perfectly on the borderline that separates plausibility and creativity.

Finally, the most creative part of the game: The Shift" component. I love how you can just move ahead to a semi in oncoming traffic so you can head-on fleeing suspects. It's really creative and unique
